text: The Lord at thy right hand shall strike through kings in the day of his wrath.
text_kjv: The Lord at thy right hand shall strike through kings in the day of his wrath.
text_niv: The Lord is at your right hand;he will crush kings on the day of his wrath.
text_esv: The Lord is at your right hand; he will shatter kings on the day of his wrath.
text_nlt: The Lord stands at your right hand to protect you.He will strike down many kings when his anger erupts.
text_msg: The Lord stands true at your side,crushing kings in his terrible wrath,
text_nasb: The Lord is at Your right hand; He will shatter kings in the day of His wrath.
context: Psalm 110 is a messianic psalm, meaning it is interpreted as pointing forward to the coming of the Messiah, Jesus Christ. Understanding its historical and cultural context requires examining the relationship between kingship and priesthood in ancient Israel and the ancient Near East. Kings often held religious authority alongside their political power, even acting as priests. This psalm breaks from that tradition, presenting a king who is also a priest 'after the order of Melchizedek' (Psalm 110:4), a figure from Genesis who predated the Levitical priesthood and represented a different, superior priestly order. The 'right hand' was a position of power and honor, signifying the Lord's active support and strength. Warfare was a central aspect of ancient Near Eastern life, and the defeat of kings represented ultimate triumph. The 'day of his wrath' alludes to a time of divine judgment, a common theme throughout the Old Testament. This wrath wasn't arbitrary but a consequence of unrighteousness and rebellion against God. Furthermore, the concept of divine kingship was prevalent. Kings were seen as God's representatives on earth, and their victories were attributed to divine favor. Psalm 110 subverts this by presenting a king empowered directly by God, a warrior-priest who defeats even the most powerful earthly rulers on the day of God's appointed judgment. The Psalm's powerful imagery and declaration of authority would have resonated deeply with its original audience familiar with themes of kingship, warfare, and divine judgment.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 110:5 speaks of the Lord's absolute power and sovereignty. The phrase 'the Lord at thy right hand' signifies God's unwavering support and active involvement in the actions of the king. This isn't just any king; it's the messianic king, Jesus Christ, who is seated at the right hand of God the Father (Hebrews 1:3). The act of 'striking through kings' represents the overcoming of all earthly opposition and the ultimate triumph of God's kingdom. The 'day of his wrath' isn't a capricious outburst but a righteous judgment against those who oppose God's will. This judgment isn't limited to literal kings; it extends to all powers and principalities that stand against God's reign. Furthermore, this verse emphasizes the active role of the Messiah in bringing about this judgment. He isn't a passive observer but an active participant in the cosmic battle between good and evil. The image of striking through kings also symbolizes the dismantling of earthly kingdoms and the establishment of God's eternal kingdom. This kingdom isn't one of earthly power and dominion but one of righteousness, peace, and justice. The verse also highlights the dual nature of the Messiah as both king and priest, fulfilling the prophecy of a ruler who wields both earthly and spiritual authority. This combination of roles allows him to effectively judge and rule, bringing about God's ultimate victory over sin and death. The defeat of kings on the day of God's wrath foreshadows the final judgment, where all will be held accountable for their actions and God's righteousness will ultimately prevail.
application: Psalm 110:5, while rooted in ancient imagery, offers profound practical applications for modern believers. Firstly, it reminds us of God's ultimate authority and power in the face of seemingly insurmountable challenges. When confronted with injustice, oppression, or personal struggles, we can find comfort in knowing that God is actively working to bring about justice and righteousness. Secondly, the verse calls us to recognize and submit to the reign of Christ in our lives. This means aligning our thoughts, actions, and desires with His teachings and values. We are to actively participate in His kingdom by living lives of love, compassion, and service to others. Thirdly, it challenges us to confront the 'kings' within ourselves – the pride, selfishness, and other sins that seek to control our lives. Just as God struck through earthly kings, He can also empower us to overcome these internal struggles and live in freedom. This requires a willingness to surrender our will to God and allow Him to transform us from the inside out. Fourthly, it calls us to be agents of justice and peace in the world. We are to stand up against injustice, advocate for the marginalized, and work towards a world where God's kingdom reigns. This can involve speaking out against oppression, supporting organizations that promote justice, and living lives that reflect God's love and compassion. Finally, the verse reminds us that the 'day of his wrath' is coming, a time when all will be held accountable for their actions. This should motivate us to live lives of integrity, striving to please God in all that we do. We should use our time and resources wisely, seeking to make a positive impact on the world and preparing ourselves for the final judgment. We should live with an eternal perspective, knowing that our actions have consequences that extend beyond this earthly life.
prayer: Heavenly Father, your word tells us that you strike through kings in the day of your wrath. Lord, I acknowledge your ultimate power and authority. I recognize that you are seated on the throne, reigning supreme over all creation. Help me to submit to your rule in every area of my life. Forgive me for the times when I have resisted your will or sought to establish my own kingdom. Empower me to overcome the 'kings' within myself – the pride, selfishness, and fear that hold me back from fully serving you. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, so that I may be a vessel of your love and justice in the world. Give me the courage to stand up against injustice and to advocate for those who are oppressed. Prepare my heart for the coming day of judgment, that I may be found faithful and pleasing in your sight. I pray all these things in the name of Jesus Christ, my Lord and Savior. Amen.

faqs.answer: The 'right hand' in Psalm 110:5 signifies a place of honor, authority, and power. It indicates that the Lord is actively supporting and empowering the king in his actions and judgments. It suggests a close relationship and divine endorsement.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does 'right hand' specifically symbolize?

faqs.answer: The 'kings' represent earthly rulers and authorities who oppose God's will and kingdom. They can also symbolize internal forces or powers of sin and darkness that resist God's reign in our lives and the world.
faqs.question: Q2: Who are the 'kings' being referred to in this verse?

faqs.answer: In the New Testament, 'the day of his wrath' refers to the final judgment when God will hold all people accountable. It's a time when justice will be fully realized, and evil will be ultimately defeated, highlighting the urgency of repentance.
faqs.question: Q3: What does 'the day of his wrath' mean in a New Testament context?

faqs.answer: This verse is often interpreted as a prophecy fulfilled in Jesus Christ. He is the messianic king who defeats the powers of darkness and establishes God's kingdom, reigning supreme over all earthly authority and bringing salvation.
